description: Partly from German rutschen (“slide”), partly (especially in Pennsylvania Dutch English) from Pennsylvania German rutsche (“slide; move around frequently”), and partly (especially in Amish use) from Plautdietsch rutschen (“slide”).

verbs.description: rutch (third-person singular simple present rutches, present participle rutching, simple past and past participle rutched)

entries.meaning: (US, informal) To slide; to scooch; to shuffle.
examples: Then Ismail set the pace yet faster, and they became the last two of a procession of turbaned men who tramped along a winding tunnel into a great mountain's womb. The sound of slippers clicking and rutching on the rock floor swelled and died and swelled again ...

entries.meaning: (especially Pennsylvania Dutch English) To squirm; to move around frequently.
